current-chamber.#text: IN THE SENATE OF THE UNITED STATES

official-title.#text:
To provide for identification of misaligned
		  currency, require action to correct the misalignment, and for other
		  purposes.

Committee on Banking, Housing, and Urban
			 Affairs

)
			 introduced the following bill; which was read twice and referred to the

short-title.#text:
Currency Exchange Rate Oversight
			 Reform Act of 2013

text.#text: This Act may be cited as the

term.#tail: means the authority referred to in

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text:
section 771(1) of the
			 Tariff Act of 1930
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Tariff Act of 1930/s:771/ss:1

term.#tail:
means the agreement referred
			 to in

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: section 101(d)(17) of the Uruguay Round Agreements Act
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Uruguay Round Agreements Act/s:101/ss:d/p:17

term.#tail:
means a
			 foreign country, dependent territory, or possession of a foreign country, and
			 may include an association of 2 or more foreign countries, dependent
			 territories, or possessions of countries into a customs union outside the
			 United States.

means the country in which the subject merchandise is produced or
			 manufactured.

means a significant and sustained undervaluation of the
			 prevailing real effective exchange rate, adjusted for cyclical and transitory
			 factors, from its medium-term equilibrium level.

means a foreign currency that is
			 in fundamental misalignment.

means a weighted average of bilateral exchange rates, expressed in
			 price-adjusted terms.

means
			 domestic monetary operations taken to neutralize the monetary impact of
			 increases in reserves associated with intervention in the currency exchange
			 market.

means the merchandise subject to an antidumping investigation, review,
			 suspension agreement, or order referred to in

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text:
section 771(25) of the Tariff Act
			 of 1930

text.#text:
On or before March 30 and September 30 of
			 each calendar year, the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Currency Exchange Rate Oversight Reform Act of 2013/s:3/ss:a

text.#text:
An analysis of currency market developments
			 and the relationship between the United States dollar and the currencies of
			 major economies and trading partners of the United States.

A review of the economic and monetary
			 policies of major economies and trading partners of the United States, and an
			 evaluation of how such policies impact currency exchange rates.

A description of any currency intervention
			 by the United States or other major economies or trading partners of the United
			 States, or other actions undertaken to adjust the actual exchange rate relative
			 to the United States dollar.

An evaluation of the domestic and global
			 factors that underlie the conditions in the currency markets, including—

trends in current and financial account
			 balances;

the size, composition, and growth of
			 international capital flows;

the impact of the external sector on
			 economic growth;

the size and growth of external
			 indebtedness;

trends in the net level of international
			 investment; and

capital controls, trade, and exchange
			 restrictions.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
, and a
			 description of any economic models or methodologies used to establish the
			 list.
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Currency Exchange Rate Oversight Reform Act of 2013/s:4/ss:a/p:2

A list of currencies designated as

term.#tail:
means a methodology under which the
				level of undervaluation of the real effective exchange rate of the currency of
				the exporting country is defined as the change in the real effective exchange
				rate needed to achieve equilibrium in the balance of payments of the exporting
				country, as such methodology is described in the guidelines of the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text:
International Monetary
				Fund’s Consultative Group on Exchange Rate Issues

term.#tail:
means a methodology under
				which the level of undervaluation of the real effective exchange rate of the
				currency of the exporting country is defined as the difference between the
				observed real effective exchange rate and the real effective exchange rate, as
				such methodology is described in the guidelines of the

means the bilateral exchange rates derived from
				converting the trade-weighted multilateral exchange rates yielded by the
				macroeconomic-balance approach and the equilibrium-real-exchange-rate approach
				into real bilateral
				terms.

quote.#text:
The fact that a subsidy may also be provided in circumstances that do
			 not involve export shall not, for that reason alone, mean that the subsidy
			 cannot be considered contingent upon export performance.
